title: Compact W-Section Beam Flexural Design (LRFD)
problem: Select the lightest W-shape beam to span 28 feet and support a uniform service dead load of 0.85 kip/ft and a uniform service live load of 1.50 kip/ft. The beam has continuous lateral support and is A992 Grade 50 steel. Use LRFD design method. Consider only flexural strength and assume the beam is compact.
required: Select the lightest W-shape beam for flexural strength.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Factored Loads
solution_steps.content:
Using LRFD load combination:

$$w_u = 1.2D + 1.6L$$

$$w_u = 1.2(0.85) + 1.6(1.50) = 1.02 + 2.40 = 3.42 \text{ kip/ft}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Factored Moment
solution_steps.content:
Maximum moment for simply supported beam with uniform load:

$$M_u = \frac{w_u L^2}{8}$$

$$M_u = \frac{3.42 \times (28)^2}{8} = \frac{3.42 \times 784}{8} = 335.2 \text{ kip-ft}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Required Plastic Section Modulus
solution_steps.content:
For compact section with continuous lateral support ($L_b \leq L_p$):

$$\phi_b M_n = \phi_b \times F_y \times Z_x$$

Setting $\phi_b M_n \geq M_u$:

$$Z_x \geq \frac{M_u}{\phi_b \times F_y}$$

Where $\phi_b = 0.90$:

$$Z_x \geq \frac{335.2 \times 12}{0.90 \times 50} = \frac{4,022.4}{45} = 89.4 \text{ in}^3$$

solution_steps.title: Select Lightest W-Section
solution_steps.content:
From AISC Manual Table 3-2 (W-Shapes sorted by $Z_x$):

- W21×44: $Z_x = 95.4$ in³ (most efficient for $Z_x > 89.4$ in³)
- W18×46: $Z_x = 90.7$ in³, weight = 46 lb/ft
- W21×44: $Z_x = 95.4$ in³, weight = 44 lb/ft
- W24×55: $Z_x = 134$ in³, weight = 55 lb/ft

**The W21×44 is the lightest section meeting the requirement.**

solution_steps.title: Verify Compact Section
solution_steps.content:
From AISC Manual Table 1-1 for W21×44:

$$\lambda_f = \frac{b_f}{2t_f} = 6.2 < \lambda_{pf} = 0.38 \sqrt{\frac{E}{F_y}} = 0.38 \times \sqrt{\frac{29,000}{50}} = 9.15$$ ✓

$$\lambda_w = \frac{h}{t_w} = 44.5 < \lambda_{pw} = 3.76 \sqrt{\frac{E}{F_y}} = 90.6$$ ✓

**Section is compact.**

solution_steps.title: Calculate Design Strength
solution_steps.content: $$\phi_b M_n = 0.90 \times 50 \times \frac{95.4}{12} = 357.8 \text{ kip-ft} > M_u = 335.2 \text{ kip-ft}$$ ✓

final_answer: Select **W21×44** (weight = 44 lb/ft) with $\phi_b M_n = 358$ kip-ft $> M_u = 335.2$ kip-ft. The beam has continuous lateral support and is compact, so the plastic moment capacity governs.

title: Beam-Column Interaction Check (LRFD)
problem: A W10×49 column is subjected to the following factored LRFD loads: $P_u = 280$ kips (axial compression) and $M_{ux} = 85$ kip-ft (strong axis bending). The column has an effective length $K_x L_x = 14$ ft (strong axis) and $K_y L_y = 12$ ft (weak axis). The column is part of a braced frame and has A992 Grade 50 steel. Check if the section is adequate using the interaction equations.
required: Check the adequacy of W10×49 using AISC interaction equations.

solution_steps.title: Determine Section Properties
solution_steps.content:
From AISC Manual Table 1-1 for W10×49:

- $A = 14.4$ in²
- $d = 10.0$ in, $b_f = 10.0$ in
- $I_x = 272$ in⁴, $I_y = 93.4$ in⁴
- $r_x = 4.35$ in, $r_y = 2.54$ in
- $Z_x = 60.4$ in³, $S_x = 54.6$ in³

From Table 3-2:
$$\phi_b M_p = \phi_b F_y Z_x = 0.90 \times 50 \times \frac{60.4}{12} = 226.5 \text{ kip-ft}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Slenderness Ratios
solution_steps.content:
$$\lambda_x = \frac{K_x L_x}{r_x} = \frac{14 \times 12}{4.35} = \frac{168}{4.35} = 38.6$$

$$\lambda_y = \frac{K_y L_y}{r_y} = \frac{12 \times 12}{2.54} = \frac{144}{2.54} = 56.7$$

$\lambda_y > \lambda_x$, so **y-axis governs** for buckling.

solution_steps.title: Determine Critical Stress and Capacity
solution_steps.content:
From AISC Manual Table 4-1 for W10×49 with $K_y L_y = 12$ ft:

$$\phi_c P_n = 423 \text{ kips}$$

Alternatively, calculate:
$$F_e = \frac{\pi^2 E}{\lambda_y^2} = \frac{\pi^2 (29,000)}{(56.7)^2} = 89.0 \text{ ksi}$$

Since $\lambda_y < 4.71\sqrt{E/F_y} = 113.4$, use Section E3:
$$F_{cr} = \left[0.658^{F_y/F_e}\right] \times F_y = \left[0.658^{50/89}\right] \times 50 = 0.785 \times 50 = 39.3 \text{ ksi}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Axial Load Ratio
solution_steps.content:
$$P_r = \frac{P_u}{\phi_c P_n} = \frac{280}{423} = 0.662$$

Since $P_r > 0.2$, use **Equation H1-1a**:
$$P_r + \frac{8}{9}(M_{rx} + M_{ry}) \leq 1.0$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Flexural Capacity
solution_steps.content:
From AISC Manual Table 3-10 for W10×49 with $C_b = 1.0$ and $L_b = 14$ ft:

Check if $L_b \leq L_p = 8.04$ ft? **No**, $L_b = 14$ ft $> L_p$.

Check if $L_b \leq L_r$: $L_r \approx 22.5$ ft $> L_b$, so **inelastic LTB governs**.

$$\phi_b M_n \approx 195 \text{ kip-ft}$$ (from Table interpolation)

final_answer: The W10×49 is **NOT adequate**. The interaction ratio is $1.05 > 1.0$. A larger section such as W10×54 or W10×60 should be selected. Alternatively, reducing the unbraced length or using a stronger steel grade would increase capacity.

title: Simple Shear Connection Design
problem: Design a single-plate shear connection using (5) 3/4-inch A325-N bolts to connect a W18×35 beam to a W12×65 column flange. The beam end reaction is $R_u = 48$ kips (LRFD factored). The beam has a cope at the bottom flange only, with a cope depth of 1.5 inches. Check the beam web for block shear rupture. Assume standard holes and A992 steel.
given: Beam: W18×35, A992 steel ($F_y = 50$ ksi, $F_u = 65$ ksi)
required: Check block shear rupture capacity of the beam web at the coped connection.

solution_steps.title: Determine Bolt Layout and Geometry
solution_steps.content:
For (5) bolts in vertical line:
- Bolt pitch = 3 in
- Edge distance $L_e = 2.5$ in
- Connection length $L_c = 4 \times 3 + 2.5 = 14.5$ in

From AISC Manual Table 1-1 for W18×35:
- $t_w = 0.300$ in
- $d = 17.70$ in

solution_steps.title: Determine Block Shear Failure Path
solution_steps.content:
For coped beam, block shear involves tension area through bolt hole line and shear area along edge.

**Tension area (single row):**
$$A_{nt} = (L_e - 0.5 d_h) \times t_w$$

Where $d_h = 13/16" = 0.875"$ for 3/4" bolt:
$$A_{nt} = (2.5 - 0.5 \times 0.875) \times 0.300 = 2.06 \times 0.300 = 0.62 \text{ in}^2$$

**Shear area:**
$$A_{gv} = L_c \times t_w = 14.5 \times 0.300 = 4.35 \text{ in}^2$$

$$A_{nv} = (L_c - 4.5 \times d_h) \times t_w = (14.5 - 4.5 \times 0.875) \times 0.300$$
$$A_{nv} = 10.56 \times 0.300 = 3.17 \text{ in}^2$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Block Shear Strength
solution_steps.content:
Per AISC Specification Section J4.3:

$$R_n = 0.6 F_u A_{nv} + U_{bs} F_u A_{nt} \leq 0.6 F_y A_{gv} + U_{bs} F_u A_{nt}$$

For single-plate connection, $U_{bs} = 1.0$.

**Option 1:**
$$R_n = 0.6(65)(3.17) + 1.0(65)(0.62) = 123.6 + 40.3 = 163.9 \text{ kips}$$

**Option 2:**
$$R_n = 0.6(50)(4.35) + 1.0(65)(0.62) = 130.5 + 40.3 = 170.8 \text{ kips}$$

**Governing $R_n = 163.9$ kips** (smaller value controls)

solution_steps.title: Calculate Design Strength
solution_steps.content: $$\phi R_n = 0.75 \times 163.9 = 122.9 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Compare to Required Strength
solution_steps.content:
$$\phi R_n = 122.9 \text{ kips} > R_u = 48 \text{ kips}$$ ✓

$$\text{Ratio} = \frac{122.9}{48} = 2.56$$ (adequate)

final_answer: The block shear capacity is $\phi R_n = 123$ kips, which exceeds the factored reaction $R_u = 48$ kips. The beam web at the coped connection is adequate for block shear rupture. Note: Additional checks for bolt shear, bearing, and flexural rupture at the coped section are also required for a complete design.

title: Tension Member Design with Staggered Holes
problem: A tension member consists of an L6×6×1/2 angle made of A572 Grade 50 steel. The angle is connected through one leg using (4) 7/8-inch diameter bolts in two lines with staggered pattern. The gage distance is $g = 2.5$ in, and the stagger distance is $s = 1.5$ in between bolt holes. Bolt spacing in each line is 3 inches. Determine the design tensile strength considering yielding, fracture, and block shear.
required: Calculate the design tensile strength $\phi P_n$ of the member.

solution_steps.title: Determine Section Properties
solution_steps.content:
From AISC Manual Table 1-7 for L6×6×1/2:

- $A_g = 5.75$ in²
- $\bar{y} = 1.68$ in

Bolt hole diameter: $d_h = 7/8 + 1/16 = 15/16 = 0.9375$ in

solution_steps.title: Calculate Yielding Strength
solution_steps.content:
Per AISC Specification Section D2:

$$P_n = F_y \times A_g = 50 \times 5.75 = 287.5 \text{ kips}$$

$$\phi P_n = 0.90 \times 287.5 = 258.8 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Fracture Strength with Staggered Holes
solution_steps.content:
Per AISC Specification Section B4.3b, for staggered holes:

$$A_n = A_g - \sum(d_h \times t) + \sum\left(\frac{s^2}{4g} \times t\right)$$

For failure path crossing both lines of holes:
$$\text{Net width reduction} = 2 \times d_h + \frac{s^2}{4g} = 2 \times 0.9375 + \frac{(1.5)^2}{4 \times 2.5}$$
$$= 1.875 + 0.225 = 2.10 \text{ in}$$

$$A_n = A_g - (\text{net width reduction}) \times t = 5.75 - 2.10 \times 0.50 = 5.75 - 1.05 = 4.70 \text{ in}^2$$

For connected leg, $A_e = A_n \times U$.
For angle with 4 bolts, $U = 0.80$ (Table D3.1, Case 8):
$$A_e = 4.70 \times 0.80 = 3.76 \text{ in}^2$$

$$P_n = F_u \times A_e = 65 \times 3.76 = 244.4 \text{ kips}$$

$$\phi P_n = 0.75 \times 244.4 = 183.3 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Block Shear Strength
solution_steps.content:
For the connected leg:

**Tension area** (assume edge distance = 1.5 in):
$$A_{nt} = (1.5 - 0.5 \times 0.9375) \times 0.5 = 0.52 \text{ in}^2$$

**Shear area** (2 lines, 4 holes):
$$A_{gv} = 2 \times (3 \times 3 + 1.5) \times 0.5 = 2 \times 10.5 \times 0.5 = 10.5 \text{ in}^2$$

$$A_{nv} = A_{gv} - 4 \times d_h \times t = 10.5 - 4 \times 0.9375 \times 0.5 = 10.5 - 1.875 = 8.625 \text{ in}^2$$

With $U_{bs} = 1.0$:
$$R_n = \min[0.6 F_u A_{nv} + U_{bs} F_u A_{nt}, \quad 0.6 F_y A_{gv} + U_{bs} F_u A_{nt}]$$

$$R_n = \min[0.6 \times 65 \times 8.625 + 65 \times 0.52, \quad 0.6 \times 50 \times 10.5 + 65 \times 0.52]$$
$$R_n = \min[336.4 + 33.8, \quad 315 + 33.8] = \min[370.2, \quad 348.8] = 348.8 \text{ kips}$$

$$\phi R_n = 0.75 \times 348.8 = 261.6 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Governing Strength
solution_steps.content:
- Yielding: $\phi P_n = 258.8$ kips
- Fracture: $\phi P_n = 183.3$ kips
- Block shear: $\phi R_n = 261.6$ kips

**Fracture governs.**

final_answer: The design tensile strength is $\phi P_n = 183$ kips, governed by **fracture through the net section with staggered holes**. The fracture capacity is lower than both yielding (259 kips) and block shear (262 kips) capacities.

title: Bolted Double-Angle Connection Design Strength
problem: A double-angle tension member (2L 4×3×5/16) is connected to a 5/8-in thick gusset plate as shown. The angles are oriented with the long legs back-to-back, separated by the thickness of the gusset plate. The connection uses 3/4-in diameter A325-N bolts (threads included in shear plane) in standard holes. The angles are ASTM A36 ($F_y = 36$ ksi, $F_u = 58$ ksi), and the gusset plate is ASTM A572 Grade 50 ($F_y = 50$ ksi, $F_u = 65$ ksi). The connection has 4 bolts in a single line (one line through each angle leg). Determine the available tensile strength (LRFD) of the double-angle member based on bolt shear, bolt bearing, and member tensile rupture. Assume the gusset plate is adequate.
given: Number of bolts: 4 in each angle leg (total 8 bolts in double angle)
Bolt spacing: 3 in (typical for connections, assumed)
required: Calculate the LRFD available tensile strength ($\phi R_n$) of the double-angle member considering the limit states of bolt shear, bolt bearing, and tensile rupture of the angles.

solution_steps.title: Determine Bolt Shear Strength
solution_steps.content:
From AISC Manual Table 7-1, for 3/4-in diameter A325-N bolts (threads included in shear plane), the available shear strength per bolt in single shear is:
$$\phi r_n = 17.9 \text{ kips/bolt}$$

There are 8 bolts in the connection (each angle has 4 bolts, total 8).

Total bolt shear strength:
$$\phi R_{n,shear} = 8 \times 17.9 = 143.2 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Bolt Bearing Strength on Angles
solution_steps.content:
From AISC Specification Section J3.10, the nominal bearing strength of a bolt on a connected part is:
$$r_n = 1.2 l_c t F_u \le 2.4 d t F_u$$

For the angle legs ($t = 5/16$ in = 0.3125 in, $F_u = 58$ ksi).

Standard hole diameter for 3/4-in bolt: $d_h = 13/16$ in = 0.8125 in (from AISC Manual Table J3.3).

**For end bolts:** Edge distance $l_e = 1.5$ in.
Clear distance from edge of hole to edge:
$$l_c = l_e - \frac{d_h}{2} = 1.5 - \frac{0.8125}{2} = 1.5 - 0.40625 = 1.09375 \text{ in}$$
$$r_{n,end} = 1.2 \times 1.09375 \times 0.3125 \times 58$$
$$r_{n,end} = 1.2 \times 1.09375 \times 18.125 = 23.77 \text{ kips}$$
Check upper limit: $2.4 d t F_u = 2.4 \times 0.75 \times 0.3125 \times 58 = 2.4 \times 0.75 \times 18.125 = 32.63$ kips.
$23.77 \le 32.63$, so $r_{n,end} = 23.77$ kips.

**For interior bolts:** Bolt spacing $s = 3.0$ in.
Clear distance between holes:
$$l_c = s - d_h = 3.0 - 0.8125 = 2.1875 \text{ in}$$
$$r_{n,int} = 1.2 \times 2.1875 \times 0.3125 \times 58$$
$$r_{n,int} = 1.2 \times 2.1875 \times 18.125 = 47.58 \text{ kips}$$
Check upper limit: $32.63$ kips (controls).

**Bearing strength per bolt (angle):**
$r_n = \min(23.77, 32.63)$ for end bolts = 23.77 kips.
$r_n = 32.63$ kips for interior bolts.

Total bearing strength for all 8 bolts:
There are 4 bolts in each angle leg. Assume 2 end bolts and 2 interior bolts per leg.

For one angle leg (4 bolts):
$$R_{n,angle} = 2 \times 23.77 + 2 \times 32.63 = 47.54 + 65.26 = 112.8 \text{ kips}$$

For double angle (2 legs):
$$R_{n,bearing,angles} = 2 \times 112.8 = 225.6 \text{ kips}$$

LRFD bearing strength (angles): $\phi = 0.75$ (for bearing at bolt holes, Section J3.10).
$$\phi R_{n,bearing,angles} = 0.75 \times 225.6 = 169.2 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Check Bearing on Gusset Plate
solution_steps.content:
Although not required for the problem, we check for completeness.

Gusset plate: $t = 5/8 = 0.625$ in, $F_u = 65$ ksi.
Upper limit: $2.4 d t F_u = 2.4 \times 0.75 \times 0.625 \times 65 = 2.4 \times 0.75 \times 40.625 = 73.13$ kips/bolt.
End bolt: $l_c = 1.09375$ in (same edge distance).
$r_{n,end,gusset} = 1.2 \times 1.09375 \times 0.625 \times 65 = 1.2 \times 1.09375 \times 40.625 = 53.32$ kips $\le 73.13$ kips.
Interior bolt: $l_c = 2.1875$ in.
$r_{n,int,gusset} = 1.2 \times 2.1875 \times 0.625 \times 65 = 106.64$ kips, but limited to 73.13 kips.
Total bearing strength on gusset (8 bolts, assuming 2 end and 6 interior):
$R_{n,gusset} = 2 \times 53.32 + 6 \times 73.13 = 106.64 + 438.78 = 545.42$ kips.
$\phi R_{n,gusset} = 0.75 \times 545.42 = 409$ kips, which is much larger than the angle bearing strength. So angles govern bearing.

solution_steps.title: Determine Tensile Rupture Strength of Angles
solution_steps.content:
From AISC Specification Section D2, for tensile rupture (fracture on net section):
$$\phi = 0.75$$
$$P_n = F_u A_e$$

First, determine gross area $A_g$ for 2L 4×3×5/16.
From AISC Manual Table 1-7, for a single L4×3×5/16, $A_g = 2.09$ in².
For double angle, $A_g = 2 \times 2.09 = 4.18$ in².

Net area $A_n$:
For standard holes, hole diameter = $d_h = 13/16 = 0.8125$ in.
For one angle leg, thickness = 5/16 in.
Hole area per bolt in one angle = $0.8125 \times 0.3125 = 0.254$ in².
For 4 bolts in one angle leg, $A_n = A_g - 4 \times 0.254 = 2.09 - 1.016 = 1.074$ in² per angle.
For double angle, $A_n = 2 \times 1.074 = 2.148$ in².

Effective net area $A_e$:
For double angles connected through one leg (long legs back-to-back), the shear lag factor $U$ must be determined.
From Table D3.1 (Case 2), for double angles with 4 or more bolts per line, $U = 0.80$ (since $\bar{x} \ge 0.5d$).
Alternatively, $U = 1 - \bar{x}/L$, with $\bar{x}$ from AISC Manual Table 1-7 for L4×3×5/16 (long leg connected). For L4×3×5/16, $\bar{x}$ (connected leg) = 0.986 in.
$L = 4 \times 3 = 12$ in (bolt group length).
$U = 1 - 0.986/12 = 0.918$.
Since Table D3.1 permits $U = 0.80$ for 4 bolts, and calculation gives 0.918, we can use $U = 0.90$ typically.
Use $U = 0.90$.

$$A_e = A_n U = 2.148 \times 0.90 = 1.933 \text{ in}^2$$

Tensile rupture strength:
$$P_n = F_u A_e = 58 \times 1.933 = 112.1 \text{ kips}$$
$$\phi P_n = 0.75 \times 112.1 = 84.1 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Governing LRFD Tensile Strength
solution_steps.content:
Compare the limit states:
- Bolt shear: $\phi R_n = 143.2$ kips
- Bolt bearing (angles): $\phi R_n = 169.2$ kips
- Tensile rupture (angles): $\phi R_n = 84.1$ kips

The smallest value governs.

$$\phi P_n = \min(143.2, 169.2, 84.1) = 84.1 \text{ kips}$$

final_answer: The LRFD available tensile strength of the double-angle member is $84.1$ kips, governed by tensile rupture of the angles.
